questions.text: Which organism cannot be grown on an Artificial culture media?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The organism which do not grow on artificial culture media are: 1. Chlamydia 2. Rickettsia 3. Ehrilichia 4. Anaplasma 5. M. leprae 6. Pathogenic Treponema

questions.text: Which of the following is used in Blood spillage?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Sodium Hypochlorite For Blood spills we use hypochlorite (sodium/calcium)

questions.text: A patient comes to the emergency with history of IV drug abuse and developed infection. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) S. Aureus Whenever the question says diabetes or I/V drug abusers, think of 2 bact:- Staph aureus & pseudomonas aeruginosa

questions.text: A patient is presented with some unknown fungal infection. On H&E staining, there is presence of sclerotic bodies having a muriform cell appearance. Which is the possible condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sclerotic /muri form or copper penny bodies = Chromoblastomycosis

questions.text: A patient, resident of Bihar, came to the OPD with history of Diabetes and complaining of multiple sinus draining in foot as shown in the image below. Identify the condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Madura foot

questions.text: Which of the following is tested before blood transfusion except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hep A Before blood transfusion, following are tested:- 1. HIV -1,2 2. HBV 3. HCV 4. VDRL 5. MP/MF

questions.text: Blood bag should be disposed in Which category bag?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Yellow

questions.text: A post Covid pt. presented to OPD with progressing black nasal discoloration, Patient was diagnosed as a case of Mucormycosis. Which of the following can by provided as a therapy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Post COVID case of mucor mycosis well be treated with amphotericin B.

questions.text: Which organism does not have cystic stage?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) All the organism mentioned have cystic stage except trichomonas-which only has trophozoite stage.

questions.text: Cat scratch disease is caused by?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1. Cat scratch disease is caused by Bartonella henselae – also causing bacillary angiomatosis (by tick)

questions.text: A person went for trekking on a mountain and had a bee-sting. Later the person developed edema, redness etc. The antibody responsible from among the following is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 1. Cat scratch disease is caused by Bartonella henselae – also causing bacillary angiomatosis (by tick) Bee sting-anaphylasis IgE. IgE

questions.text: In Rh incompatibility the mechanism that is involved causing the reaction is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cytotoxic 1. Rh in compatibility blood group mismatching = type II or cystotoxic immune reaction 2. Type III – immune complex deposition 3. Type I = allergic/anaphylactic 4. Type IV = delayed

questions.text: Earliest cell involved in inflammation amongst the following is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Neutrophil is the earliest all involved in inflammation

questions.text: A child has complains of recurrent infections. Investigations showed thymic hypoplasia and hypocalcemia was also seen. Which of the following disease is associated with the scenario mentioned
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Digeorge syndrome Thymic hypoplasia and hypocalcemia-Digorge syndrome Mnemonic = CATCH 22 C – Cardia (TOF) A – Atypical facies T –Thymic aplasia C – Cleft palate H – Hypo parathyroidism/ hypocalcemia 22 = deletion of 22qII

questions.text: A patient presented with discolored patches on the skin. Microscopic image of the organism showed "Spaghetti and meatballappearance". Identify the organism
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Malassezia furfur If east with short hyphae showing spaghetti meatball app or banana & grapes app = Malasezzia furfur.

questions.text: A patient came to hospital with complain of fever and headache. On examination black necrotic area was noted on the bridge of the nose along with swelling on one side of the face. What is the most important risk factor involved in this infection
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Diabetic ketoacidosis Black necrotic area on bridge of nose = mucormycosis = diabetic ketoacidosis

questions.text: A patient has complains of fever and rigorous chills. Microscopic examination image is shown below. Identify the organism
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Plasmodium falciparum In the image, we can see banana/boat shaped gametocytes – plasmodium falciparum

questions.text: A child has fever, runny nose, headache and a rash as shown in the image. The disease was caused by SS-DNA virus. Identify the disease
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Erythema infectiosum In the image we can see slapped check app. ∴ It is the inf. By 5th disease aka Erythema infectiosum, caused by Parvovirus B19

questions.text: A child was brought to the hospital with swelling around pinna, painful salivary glands and testicular swelling. Identify the causative organism
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Painful salivary glands (parotitis) and testicular swelling = mumps virus.

questions.text: A patient admitted with the complaints of severe headache, fever, nuchal rigidity. A lumbar puncture was performed that showed Protein 1.0 g/L, glucose 2.2 mmol/L, white cell count 150/mm3, 90% polymorphs. On microscopy the organism was noted to have differential motility i.e tumbling motility at 25° and non-motile at 37°. Identify the organism
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Listeria Painful salivary glands (parotitis) and testicular swelling = mumps virus. Bacteria has tumbling motility at 250C and is non motile at 37?C = listeria

questions.text: A patient is admitted due to complains of fever, cough, Shortness of Breath, Splinter hemorrhages. Vegetations on the valve were noted. The organism was found to be a cocci in chains, Optochin and bile solubility test resistant. Which of the following organisms is most likely associated?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Streptococcus sanguis Severe headache, fever & nuchal Rigidity = meningitis + cocci present in chains ? Streptococcus sanguis, S. viridians

questions.text: Condyloma acuminata is caused by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Human papilloma virus Condyloma accuminata is caused by human papilloma virus 6 & 11.

questions.text: A patient was treated with clindamycin for a recent infection. Shortly after the antibiotic course is complete, the patient develops diarrhea. What is the most likely causative organism in this scenario?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Clostridium difficile Antibiotic use diarrhea is due to clostridium difficle

questions.text: A child was brought to the hospital with complains of fever, difficulty swallowing. On examination edema on the neck and a grayish-white coating was noted over the throat that started to bleed on an attempt to scrape it. Identify the organism associated
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Corynebacterium diphtheriae 1. In the ques, is mentioned a case where bacteria causes grayish white coating on the throat which bleeds if we attempt to scrape it = Corynebacterium diphtheria.

questions.text: Granuloma inguinale is caused by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Klebsiella granulomatis

questions.text: A female presented with a vaginal discharge. Microscopic examination showed clue cells. Drug preferred for the treatment among the following is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Metronidazole

questions.text: A TB patient shows resistance to Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Kanamycin & fluoroquinolone. This type is resistance is known as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Extensively drug resistant (XDR) TB If Resistance to isoniazid, rifampicin, kanyamycin & fluoroquinolone is present, we would classify it as extensively drug resistance TB.

questions.text: A child with a history of sore-throat was later found to have cola- colored urine. What is the most likely diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Streptococcus pyogenes Sore throat +Puffed face +Cola coloured Urine = strep pyogens.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with TB. Which of the following stains would be used
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) ZN stain Stain for TB = Zeihl Nelson stain (ZN stain)

questions.text: E.coli can be best grown on among the following
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) MacConkey agar E.coli can be best grown in Mac Conkey agar while the other three are for salmonella & Shigella.

questions.text: Antibody dependent enhancement is seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Previous antibodies can enhance the infection in dengue.

questions.text: Cheap test for diagnosis of Syphilis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) RPR Cheap & easy test for Syphilis is RPR

questions.text: Only dimorphic fungus which is also a subcutaneous mycosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Sporothrix schenckii 1. Systemic mycosis =blastomyces dermatiditis & histoplasma capsulatum 2. Opportunistic = penicillium marneffi 3. Subcutaneous = sporothrix sehenckii = Rose gardener’s

questions.text: The following image is indicative of which of the given diseases?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cytomegalovirus disease In the image we can see owl eye app. Seen in cytomegalovirus disease.

questions.text: Adult male with multiple sexual partners presented with Genital ulcer. What is the next IOC?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Dark field microscopy 1. Genital ulcers (STI) s/o spirochetes

questions.text: A female presented with foul smelling vaginal discharge. Microscope revealed motile protozoa. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Trichomoniasis The foul swelling discharged caused by motile protozoa = Trichomoniasis

questions.text: Traumatic implantation in a forest worker followed by formation of a cauliflower like/ verrucous growth?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Chromoblastomycosis Cauliflower like growth on gross exam and copper penny app on HPE = Chromoblastomycosis

questions.text: Cattle farmer with lesion on the arm. Microscopic examination shows brick/ box shaped gram-positive organism with squared ends and spores in the center. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Bacillus anthracis Brick/box shaped gram positive organism = Bacillus anthracis

questions.text: Culture media used to differentiate lactose vs non lactose fermenters?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) MacConkey agar

questions.text: Ab present in highest concentration in the blood
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) IgG Highest concentration = IgG Highest half life = IgG

questions.text: Image shown here is used for the diagnosis of-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) HSV The given image shows Tzanck smear which is a rapid, diagnostic method for Herpes simplex virus. Tzanck cells are multinucleate giant cells with ground glass chromatin.

questions.text: Macrophages in liver are named as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Kupffer cells Macrophage in:- 1. Skin = Langerhan’s cell 2. Spleen = Littoral cell 3. Kidney = mesangial cells 4. Liver = kupffer cells

questions.text: Which of the following is an Acid fast organism
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) M. avium Acid fast organisms:- 1. M. avium 2. Noocardia 3. Candida 4. Bac. Spores 5. MTB

questions.text: The stain used for identifying Cryptococcus is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) India ink stain India ink is a negative staining method that provides a uniformly coloured background. The unstained organisms stand out in contrast to the background. It is useful in the demonstration of organisms with capsules that do not take simple stains. It is also used to stain slender bacteria like spirochetes. Cryptococcus is a globular encapsulated yeast with a polysaccharide capsule which is seen against a black background.

questions.text: Plasma sterilisation is done by-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hydrogen peroxide Plasma sterilisation is done with hydrogen peroxide. The mechanism of action is a free radical injury with hydrogen peroxide. Arthroscopes, ureteroscope, etc are sterilised by Plasma sterilisation. Sterilisation control is Geobacillus stearothermophilus and Bacillus atrophaeus.

questions.text: Which among the following culture media is used in the identification of Salmonella?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Wilson and Blaire medium Wilson and Blaire medium is a type of selective and indicator media. Salmomella typhi reduces sulphite to sulphide in the presence of glucose and produces jet black colonies with a metallic sheen due to production of H2S on Wilson and Blaire sulphite medium.

questions.text: Which among the following parasites directly invade the skin?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Schistosoma mansoni The parasite that directly invade the skin is Schistosoma mansoni .Following skin penetration by cercariae, a pruritic rash termed cercarial dermatitis or swimmers itch develops locally which is self limiting.

questions.text: A 45 year old man with multiple sexual partners presents with a palmoplantar rash as seen below. On examination, he has epitrochlear lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Secondar syphilis The clinical scenario of maculopapular rash with flu-like symptoms and epitrochlear lymphadenopathy points to secondary syphilis. Rash over the palms and soles is seen in Coxsackie A virus, Rocky mountain spotted fever and secondary syphilis.

questions.text: Which of the following hepatitis viruses is likely to get transmitted via feco-oral route?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hepatitis A Hepatitis A gets transmitted via feco-oral route. Hepatitis B, C and D can occur sexually.

questions.text: A patient presented with infective endocarditis 6 month after prosthetic valve implantation. What may be the etiological agent?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) PVIE less than one year – Staph epidermidis PVIE More than one year – Strep viridans

questions.text: Patient developed diarrhea after sea food consumption. Organism exhibits Kanagawa phenomenon. Choose the correct etiological agent.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Vibrio parahaemolyticus associated with sea food (Shell fish) poisoning. It exhibits Kanagawa phenomenon. Produces hemolysis in Wagatsuma agar.

questions.text: Farmer with traumatic ulcer in eye, septate hyphae seen in microscopy. Etiological agent is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Fungi with septate hyphae causes ulcer in eye suggestive of Aspergillus. Mucor is non-septate hyphae. Pseudomonas and Staphylococcus are bacterias

questions.text: Type 2 lepra reaction belongs to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Lepra reaction 2 and 3 belongs to type III HSR. Lepra reaction 1 belongs to type IV HSR.

questions.text: Patient with diarrhea. Stool microscopy revealed pathogen exhibits falling leaf motility with 4 pairs of flagella. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pear shape trophozoite with falling leaf motility suggestive of Giardia lamblia. It causes steatorrhea, megaloblastic anaemia and traveler's diarrhea. Treatment Metronidazole

questions.text: Cholera toxin binding receptor is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Vibrio cholerae produces cholera toxin. Cholera toxin binds to GM1 ganglioside receptors and stimulates adenyl cyclase. It increases cAMP and causes secretory diarrhea.

questions.text: A neonate admitted with the features of meningitis. Bacteria isolated from CSF is bacitracin resistant. Choose the correct pathogen.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Most common cause of Neonatal meningitis are GBS, E. coli and Listeria. GBS is bacitracin resistant.

questions.text: Bacillus anthracis belongs to bioterrorism agent
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bacillus anthracis belongs to bioterrorism agent category A. Other examples are Plague, Botulinum toxin, Tularaemia, smallpox, Ebola

questions.text: TB in PLHIV with CD < 35 cells is best made by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) All PLHIV should be tested for TB. Best initial test to screen for TB is CBNAAT. Rapid and reliable test. It can detect Tuberculosis and drug resistance. Example Genexpert and Trunat.

questions.text: ARF and PSGN due to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) ARF and PSGN are non suppurative manifestations of GAS. It is due to molecular mimicry.

questions.text: Corneal scrapping obtained from a patient presented with hydrophobia. Choose the best test
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Best test for corneal scrapping specimen is RT-PCR. In Brain biopsy we can demonstrate Negribodies. Corneal impression smear – Immunofluorescence.

questions.text: Treatment for CMV retinitis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Treatment for CMV infections are Gancyclovir, Valgancyclovir and foscarnet.

questions.text: All the following associated with exotoxins except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) EHEC157: H7 toxin – HUS Toxin A & B of C. difficle – Pseudomembranous colitis TSST of S. aureus - TSS

questions.text: 20 year old boy was immunized 7 years ago. Currently he had an injury. what will we give him now
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Previously immunized – no Tig. Currently no TT. Single dose Td need to be given.

questions.text: Image shown here is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) It’s a case of elephantiasis Lymphatic filariasis Caused by W. bancrofti.

questions.text: Diagnosis based on the image
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Clue cells are diagnostic for bacterial vaginosis Caused by G. vaginalis.

questions.text: Hepatocellular carcinoma caused
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Aflatoxin produced by Aspergillus flavus. It produces Hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: Penicil shape macroconidia seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Penicil shape Macroconidia – Trichophyton Club shape – Epidermophyton Spindle shape - Microsporum

questions.text: Plasmodium species affecting brain
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) P. falciparum

questions.text: PLHIV with Fever, neck rigidity, Altered sensorium. India ink stain positive for CSF. Choose the correct agent
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Cryptococcus

questions.text: Reservoir for Kala Azar is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Human

questions.text: Patient with ARF. Blood culture shows GPC in chains. Etiological Agent
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Strep Pyogenes

questions.text: Partner treatment indicated in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Herpes

questions.text: Pt with meningitis. Lymphocytes seen in CSF. Etiology
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) M. tuberculosis The presence of lymphocytes in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is a key diagnostic feature of tuberculous meningitis. The body's immune response to the Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacterium is a chronic, cell-mediated one that involves a lymphocytic pleocytosis, where lymphocytes are the predominant white blood cell type found in the CSF. In contrast, the other three options (S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae, and N. meningitidis) are common causes of acute bacterial meningitis, which typically presents with a high count of neutrophils in the CSF.

questions.text: Pt with crushed limb after amputation develops crepitus. diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Gas gangrene

questions.text: A truck driver came with painful genital ulcer and lymph nodes. H/o unprotected sex present. Choose the correct clinical condition
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Chancroid

questions.text: Patient came with fever and chills. Peripheral smear shown in the image. Choose the pathogen.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

choices.text: ADP ribosylation of EF2 - Inhibiting protein synthesis

questions.text: Diphtheria toxin MoA is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Vector for Scrub typhus / Orientia tsutsugamushi is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Mite

questions.text: Outbreak of diarrhoea. Rice water stool in nature. Pathogen exhibited darting motility. Culture media shown in image. What is the organism
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Normal flora of Conjunctiva is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: A peripheral smear shown in the image revealed the diagnosis. Choose the correct treatment.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient present with fatigue and tired-ness. He had low Hb and Reticulocyte count. BM reveals decrease is erythroid precursors. What is the diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: A PLHIV with low CD4 count admitted with pneumonia. GMS stain of BAL shown in the image. Choose the correct agent.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pneumocystis

questions.text: Kaposi sarcoma present in Which CD4 count?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) < 200 • Kaposi sarcoma is most commonly seen when CD4 < 200, especially < 150. • While it can occasionally occur below 500, it’s not common above 200. • MCQs like this test the threshold where risk significantly rises, and that’s 200.

questions.text: A 65 year old PLHIV patient came with Cough, fever and pneumonia. Biopsy shown in the image. Choose the correct agent.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Patient with bloody diarrhoea. Flask shaped ulcers seen. Infection due to ingestion of quadrinucleate cysts. What is the appropriate treatment?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Metronidazole

questions.text: Identify the pathogen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Epidermophyton

questions.text: A patient sample positive for Infectious Hepatitis B. Choose the correct marker for this condition
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) HBsAg + HBe When a patient sample is positive for "Infectious Hepatitis B," the combination of HBsAg positive and HBeAg negative (HBsAg + HBe -) is a highly relevant and increasingly common marker for a transmissible infection. HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen) is the primary indicator of current Hepatitis B infection, whether acute or chronic. Its mere presence means the virus is in the body and can be transmitted. The "HBe -" component indicates that the patient is in a phase of the disease known as HBeAg-negative chronic hepatitis B, or they may be in an inactive carrier state. Critically, patients in the HBeAg-negative phase are still infectious and capable of transmitting the virus, often with detectable HBV DNA (viral load), though perhaps at lower levels than the highly replicating HBeAg-positive phase. Given the global prevalence of HBeAg-negative chronic hepatitis B, recognizing HBsAg positivity as the core marker of infectivity, even in the absence of HBeAg, is essential for identifying all potentially infectious individuals. Therefore, HBsAg positivity makes the patient infectious, and the HBeAg negativity specifies a common and still transmissible subtype of infection. Incorrect Responses: A. HBeAg: While HBeAg is a strong indicator of high viral replication and high infectivity, it doesn't encompass all forms of infectious Hepatitis B. A significant proportion of chronically infected individuals, especially in certain geographical regions, are HBeAg-negative but still have active infection and are capable of transmission due to viral mutations. Thus, relying solely on HBeAg would miss a large subset of "infectious Hepatitis B" cases. C. HBcAg: Hepatitis B core antigen (HBcAg) is located inside the liver cells infected by the virus. It is generally not found or detected in the peripheral blood and is therefore not a serological marker used for diagnosing infectivity from a blood sample. Blood tests typically look for antibodies against HBcAg (Anti-HBc), not the antigen itself. D. HBs + Anti Hbe (HBsAg positive + Anti-HBe positive): This profile indicates a patient with chronic Hepatitis B (HBsAg positive) who has developed antibodies against HBeAg. This usually signifies a phase of reduced viral replication and lower infectivity compared to the HBeAg-positive state. While these individuals still have an ongoing infection and can potentially transmit the virus, this combination typically represents a less active and less "infectious" phase than the HBeAg-positive state, or even the HBeAg-negative chronic hepatitis B with high viral load. It suggests a degree of immune control.

questions.text: A patient positive for HBsAg and AntiHBc -IgM. What is the diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Acute hepatitis

choices.text: Inhibits the release of Acetyl Choline

questions.text: MoA of botulinum toxin is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Inhibits the release of Acetyl Choline

questions.text: A person with the H/o long term sexual relationship presented with painful ulcers on his genitals with tender lymphadenopathy. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Chancroid

questions.text: A 70-year-old man admitted with a murmur and blood culture positive for Gram Positive cocci. Choose the common agent causing prosthetic valve infective endocarditis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Staphylococcus epidermidis

questions.text: A group of friends consumed fried rice in a restaurant. Six hours later they start vomiting. What is the etiological agent?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bacillus cereus

questions.text: A Tzanck smear prepared from a vesicle shows multinucleated giant cells. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) HSV

questions.text: A farmer presents with fever and sub conjunctival hemorrhage. Microscopic agglutination test turn to be positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Leptospira

questions.text: A newborn present with Bi lateral sensory neuronal hearing loss with salt and pepper retinopathy. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Rubella

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with Cryptococcal meningitis. What is the treatment
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Flucytosine + L.Amp

questions.text: A PLHIV admitted with headache, altered sensorium. CSF India ink positive revealed the pathogen. Choose the correct organism
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cryptococcus neoformans

questions.text: A firefighter admitted with fever with cough, Culture shown in the image reveals gram negative, oxidase positive bacilli. Colonies transilluminating while passing under UV light. Choose the correct agent
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pseudomonas

questions.text: A person came with the H/o thorn prick a week ago. Few days later he developed ulcers along lymphatic drainage. Choose the correct organism
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Sporothrix schenckii

questions.text: A Patient with cough diagnosed as TB. Choose the correct Selective medium
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Lowenstein Jensen medium

questions.text: A PLHIV came with multiple dog bites with punctured wound. Choose the correct management
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Local Treatment+ Rig + Vaccine

questions.text: A patient admitted with fever and nuchal rigidity. CSF analysis shows decreased glucose and increased protein and neutrophils. Choose the correct treatment
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ceftriaxone

questions.text: Toughness of bacterial cell wall is due to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Peptidoglycan

questions.text: KAT G mutation associated with
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Isoniazid

questions.text: Diagnosis of Rickettsial antibody, Proteus antigens are used in a test. Name the Antigen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Heterophile antigen

questions.text: A patient presents with pain and redness in the eye; She wear contact lens and admits maintaining poor lens hygiene. Most common causative agent involved in this condition is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Contact lens wearers with poor hygiene are at risk for Acanthamoeba keratitis—a protozoal infection causing severe eye pain and corneal ulcers. Most common cause is Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

questions.text: A woman was bitten by a rabid dog. The dog develops symptoms and dies with in a week. Best method for antemortem diagnosis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) DFAT (Direct Fluorescent Antibody Test) - For antemortem diagnosis of rabies in humans, DFAT on corneal/salivary smears is preferred. Negri bodies from brain biopsy by seller stain are post-mortem findings.

questions.text: A HIV positive patient admitted with dry cough and breathlessness. CD4 count is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Pneumocystis In HIV patients with CD4

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with whitish plaques in the oral cavity. A KOH mount confirms the presence of budding yeast with pseudohyphae. Which of the following is the most appropriate culture medium for isolation of this organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sabouraud dextrose agar For Candida albicans, SDA is the standard medium. Chocolate agar is enriched medium Thayer-Martin for Neisseria Loeffler's is for Corynebacterium.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with multiple small, skin-colored papules with central umbilication over the trunk and face. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Molluscum contagiosum Umbilicated papules on skin in children suggest Molluscum contagiosum, caused by a poxvirus. It produces Henderson Peterson bodies

questions.text: Painful vesicular lesions seen in fingers. Tzanck smear shown multinucleated giant cells. What is the organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Herpes simplex virus Herpetic whitlow presents with vesicular lesions on fingers. Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells.

questions.text: A traveler is moving from Nigeria to the United States. Which vaccine must he receive as part of international health regulations?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 17D (Yellow fever vaccine) 17D (Yellow fever vaccine) - WHO mandates Yellow Fever vaccine (17D) for travelers from endemic zones (e.g., Nigeria) to non-endemic countries.

questions.text: HPV infection is most commonly associated with which type of cancer?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Oropharyngeal cancer HPV (especially types 16, 18) is most associated with cervical and oropharyngeal cancers. It also causes anorectal cancers

questions.text: A 30-year-old man develops profuse vomiting and diarrhea within 3 hours of consuming pre-packaged salad and milk at a picnic. There is no fever. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Staphylococcus aureus Rapid-onset food poisoning (<6h) without fever suggests preformed enterotoxin of S. aureus. Salads is another clue

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presents with diarrhea. Stool microscopy reveals oocysts measuring 22 microns containing double wall bounded cyst. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cystoisospora belli 22-micron oocysts with double wall indicate Cystoisospora belli. Cyclospora is 8-12 ?m Cryptosporidium oocysts are ~5–10 ?m.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever after returning from a forest trip. On examination, a black eschar is noted on the abdomen. Which of the following is the most likely treatment?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Doxycycline Black eschar after forest exposure = Scrub typhus (Orientia tsutsugamushi). DOC = Doxycycline.

questions.text: Borderline Tuberculoid leprosy belongs to which type of Hypersensitivity Reaction:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Type IV Borderline tuberculoid leprosy is mediated by Type IV hypersensitivity (delayed T-cell response).

questions.text: A child presents with fever and sore throat. Throat swab culture on Chocolate agar reveals Gram negative coccobacilli. Which of the following organisms is it most likely?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Haemophilus influenzae Fastidious gram-negative coccobacillus grown on chocolate agar with X (hemin) and V (NAD) factors. Listeria and S. pneumoniae are Gram positive bacteria Parainfluenza is virus

questions.text: A 3-month-old child admitted with pneumonia. Microscopy shown in the image. Choose the correct organism.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Influenza Virus structure with Hemagglutinin and Neuraminidase suggestive of Influenza virus Common cause of pneumonia/bronchiolitis in infants but this virus lacks H and N

questions.text: A patient admitted with fever and altered sensorium. Peripheral smear shown multiple ring forms in RBCs. Cerebral malaria is diagnosed. Organism found resistant chloroquine. What is the treatment for it?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Artesunate Plasmodium falciparum with cerebral signs + chloroquine resistance ? IV artesunate is preferred.

questions.text: Identify the clinical condition shown in the image
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) Caused by exfoliative toxin of S. aureus. Seen in neonates/children; skin peeling with erythema.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male admitted with fever, Headache, retro orbital pain with rash. Torniquet test is positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Dengue hemorrhagic fever Fever, retro-orbital pain, rash, +ve tourniquet test = classic Dengue.

questions.text: A diabetic patient present with black lesion in face with nasal crusts. What is the treatment?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Amphotericin B Diabetics with black nasal lesions ? Mucormycosis. DOC = Liposomal Amphotericin B.

questions.text: 4-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with complaints of sore throat and low-grade fever. On physical examination, multiple vesicular lesions are noted on the palms, soles, and oral mucosa as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Coxsackievirus A16 Vesicles on palms, soles, mouth = Hand-Foot-Mouth Disease, caused by Coxsackie A16.

questions.text: A woman presents with sudden-onset high-grade fever, hypotension, diffuse rash, and a history of using a vaginal tampon during her menstruation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Streptococcus agalactiae infection

questions.text: A 35-year-old farmer presents with fever, malaise, and diarrhea for 5 days. On further history, he reports regular exposure to livestock, including cattle and goats. There is no history of tick or flea bite and there is no rash on examination. Which of the following organisms is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Coxiella burnetii Zoonotic fever, no rash or tick bite ? Q fever caused by C. burnetii from cattle/goats.

questions.text: In an experimental study involving antigen injection in humans to study immune response, which of the following antibodies appears first after antigen exposure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) IgM IgM is the first antibody produced in primary immune response. Millionaire molecule Used to confirm congenital infections.

questions.text: A person came with fever, Calf pain and night sweats. H/o consumption of unpasteurized milk is present. Choose the correct treatment
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Doxycycline + Rifampicin Brucellosis (fever, night sweats, unpasteurized milk) is treated with Doxy + Rifampicin for 6 weeks.

questions.text: A patient admitted with severe pain and the presence of gas bubbles that produce crepitus. Choose the correct causative agent?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Clostridium histolyticum Gas gangrene with crepitus can be caused by C. perfringens, but C. histolyticum is also gas-producing.

questions.text: Culture medium for Sporothrix is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Sabouraud dextrose agar Sporothrix schenckii is isolated on SDA. Niger seed is for Cryptococcus. Ashdown medium for Burkholderia pseudomallei
